Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Story: I stared at my calendar, heart pounding. The family gathering had been planned for weeks—my daughter had even called to remind me how much the grandkids were looking forward to baking cookies together. I could already picture their flour-dusted faces and the laughter echoing through the kitchen. But then, an email notification blinked on my screen: the final team meeting was set for the exact same afternoon. My manager’s message was clear—everyone’s input was crucial before we locked in the new project direction. I knew my colleagues expected me to be present, to contribute my experience and insights. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My family wanted my warmth and attention, my team needed my expertise and commitment. I could almost hear my granddaughter’s disappointed sigh if I missed the gathering, and I could imagine the awkward silence in the meeting if my chair sat empty. My mind raced, torn between the joy of family and the responsibility of work, unable to see how I could possibly be in two places at once.
